awd_titl_txt: Barnard Robert Noyce Teacher Scholars Progam
awd_abstract_narration:
The Barnard College Robert Noyce Teacher Education Scholars Program (BNTSP) is a partnership engaging the following New York City high-needs schools:  Bronx School of Law and Finance, Central Park East Secondary School, James Baldwin High School, and the Emily Dickinson Elementary School (PS 75).  The project recruits, certifies, and mentors 16 high-achieving undergraduate mathematics and science majors to become K-12 teachers.  As a college for women, the BNTSP works to increase the number of women who teach and serve as role models and mentors for girls in STEM fields.  The BNTSP serves as a model for recruitment, preparation, induction, and retention of high-quality science and mathematics teachers for high-need schools, including the design, implementation, and evaluation of a collaborative, web-based, STEM teacher learning environment, which provides scholars with peer, faculty, and mentor support during student teaching and their first two years of teaching.

Internships, scholarships, and a funded ninth semester option ensure that teacher candidates in mathematics and science can complete requirements for their STEM major and initial New York State certification in elementary or secondary education.  BNTSP's STEM Colloquia, which bring STEM experts to the campus for a series of talks or workshops focused on STEM educational issues, are open to the school partners, the university, and the public, ensuring broad participation in the presentation, dissemination, and discussion of K-12 STEM education issues. The associated STEM Discussion course, which enrolls Barnard and Columbia undergraduates, provides students with interest in STEM education a venue to explore those interests in greater depth with other students who share their interests. By hosting BNTSP's STEM Field Explorations, faculty members have the opportunity to share their science and mathematics expertise with teachers from partner schools, members of Barnard's New Teacher Network, and potential Barnard Noyce scholars.  STEM Field Explorations contribute to building teachers' expertise by modeling use of the unique resources of New York City to teach science and mathematics. 

Scholarly publications emanating from the BNTSP focus on the impact of the project on teacher's self-efficacy in terms of their beliefs about their: a) knowledge of science content; b) knowledge of science teaching methods; c) ability to respond to students' questions; d) ability to impact student learning in science or mathematics; and e) confidence in teaching students from underrepresented groups in high-needs schools. The comprehensive project evaluation plan ensures the development of evidence-based assertions about the impact of program initiatives and innovations on STEM teacher recruitment, development, and retention.

Strategies to ensure broad dissemination of the data and results of this project include the BNTSP website, conference presentations, peer-reviewed publications, and the deposit of project data in the Academic Commons, a digital research repository at Columbia University with global access.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the Barnard Noyce Teacher Scholars Program (BNTSP) were to recruit, certify, and mentor 16 high-achieving mathematics and science majors at Barnard College to become K-12 teachers in high-need schools, and to build engagement with STEM educational issues at Barnard and in the broader community. As a college for women, the BNTSP worked to increase the number of women who teach and serve as role models and mentors for girls in STEM fields. The project's broader impacts will carry on as these teachers continue to work in high-need and other schools where they can foster their students' achievement in science and mathematics, laying the foundation for their advanced studies in STEM fields. The project included:

1.     Recruitment activities designed to build awareness of STEM education issues on campus and to attract high-quality teacher candidates to the program. Recruitment activities include the STEM Colloquium Speaker Series, STEM Colloquium Discussion Course, STEM Field Explorations, and the Summer Internship Program.

2.     Internships, scholarships, and a funded 9th-semester option to support teacher candidates in mathematics and science, so that they can complete requirements for their major and for initial New York State certification in elementary or secondary education.

3.     Mentoring and professional development activities designed to retain the teacher candidates in the program, and to ensure that our graduates experienced successful induction and retention in high-need schools.

By all measures, the project successfully met all its goals. A total of 16 scholars (12 undergraduates and 4 graduate students) completed their education and teacher certification with scholarship support from the Barnard Noyce Teacher Scholars Program. Internships, scholarships, and a funded ninth semester option ensured that teacher candidates in mathematics and science could complete requirements for their STEM major and initial New York State certification in elementary or secondary education. BNTSP's STEM Colloquia, brought STEM experts to the campus for a series of talks or workshops focused on STEM educational issues, and were open to our school partners, the university, and the public, ensuring broad participation in the presentation, dissemination, and discussion of K-12 STEM education issues. The associated STEM Discussion course, which enrolled Barnard and Columbia undergraduates, provided students with interest in STEM education a venue to explore those interests in greater depth with other students who shared their interests. By hosting BNTSP's STEM Field Explorations, faculty members had the opportunity to share their science and mathematics expertise with teachers from partner schools, members of Barnard's New Teacher Network, and potential Barnard Noyce scholars. STEM Field Explorations contributed to building teachers' expertise by modeling use of the unique resources of New York City to teach science and mathematics.

Thirty-three summer internships were awarded under the grant ranging from: the Eli and Edythe Broad CIRM Center for Regenerative Medicine and Stem Cell Research, the New York State Psychiatric Institute, the NYC Department of Parks and Recreation, the Barnard Microbial Lab, Lab, Columbia University Teachers College, MD Anderson Cancer Center, the New York Botanical Garden Herbarium, Breakthrough Collaborative, Columbia University Medical Center, Gladstone Institute for Virology and Immunology, Undergraduate Phenotyping of Arabidopsis Knockouts (UNPAK) project, the Jia Lab at Columbia University, the Snow Lab at Barnard, the Crowther Lab at Barnard, and the Sever Lab at Barnard. In addition, in partnership with Harlem Grown, summer interns helped develop and implement an urban gardening curriculum.

Among the highlights of the project, Noyce Scholars report that the mentoring they received through the Barnard Noyce Teacher Scholars program has had a positive impact on their induction and retention. Scholars report a sense of self-efficacy in their classrooms especially in relation to being open to considering new ideas and approaches, accepting constructive feedback from more experienced teachers, connecting with all students regardless of race/ethnicity, socio-economic status, or family situation, and seeking guidance when not sure how to handle a new situation. Nearly all scholars have a high degree of confidence in their abilities to plan interesting lessons, organize class time efficiently, deal with difficult classroom situations and manage many other aspects of teaching. Barnard Noyce Scholars have earned Masters degrees in Science and Mathematics Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, a Masters in education from SUNY Albany and Bank Street College, and a Masters degree in Special Education at Brooklyn College. One of our Noyce Scholars has received a prestigious Knowles Teaching Fellowship and a Math for America Early Career Fellowship.
